trustfund:
TF053326-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT,TF055804-PHRD-ALBANIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT-860458

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Modernization Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: the Program was able to
            achieve success because reforms spanned key areas of the
            health care system starting with the stewardship functions
            of the Ministry of Health (MOH) in health policy development
            and the Health Insurance Institute (HII) in health financing
            and provider payment reforms. The capacity of the Government
            to absorb technical assistance and implement complex
            institutional changes should be carefully evaluated to
            ensure knowledge transfer and a sustainable impact of the
            activities started under the Project. Close coordination and
            collaboration with United States Agency for International
            Development (USAID), World Health Organization (WHO), and
            Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) in supporting
            implementation aspects of the program helped keep key
            activities on track and ensured complementarities of
            interventions. Since both the PIU and the Bank have no
            built-in capacity for the review of technical specifications
            and bid evaluation reports of medical equipment, the launch
            of procurement for medical equipment should allow more time
            in the procurement plan for the review of bidding documents
            and bid evaluation reports. Moreover, the bid validity
            period should also be for a longer period to avoid extension
            of bid validity period. The development and integration of
            health information systems in the health sector is complex.
            If a sector needs intervention in the implementation of a
            new information system, it is important that there is a
            specific team working on it right from the beginning of the
            Project, and adequate time, resources, and attention should
            be given on a priority basis. It will be important for the
            Bank to find a way to keep supporting the follow-up actions
            of the reforms introduced under the Project. Without a
            follow-on project, the Bank will not have leverage with the
            government regarding the reforms introduced.
